title: CHADS₂ Score for Atrial Fibrillation Stroke Risk
description: Clinical prediction tool that estimates annual stroke risk in patients with atrial fibrillation. Helps determine whether anticoagulation therapy is warranted based on patient's risk profile for thromboembolic events. Developed from the National Registry of Atrial Fibrillation and validated in multiple populations.

parameters.name: congestive_heart_failure
parameters.description: History of congestive heart failure or left ventricular dysfunction

parameters.name: hypertension
parameters.description: History of hypertension or current antihypertensive treatment

parameters.name: diabetes_mellitus
parameters.description: History of diabetes mellitus or current antidiabetic treatment

parameters.name: stroke_tia_thromboembolism
parameters.description: Previous stroke, transient ischemic attack, or thromboembolism

result.name: chads2_assessment
result.description: CHADS₂ score with annual stroke risk assessment and anticoagulation recommendations

ranges.interpretation: CHADS₂ Score 0: Low stroke risk (1.9% per year). Consider further risk stratification with CHA₂DS₂-VASc score. May consider aspirin or observation based on bleeding risk and patient preferences.
CHADS₂ Score 1: Low-intermediate stroke risk (2.8% per year). Consider further risk stratification with CHA₂DS₂-VASc score or anticoagulation based on bleeding risk assessment.
CHADS₂ Score 2: Intermediate stroke risk (4.0% per year). Anticoagulation generally recommended unless contraindicated due to bleeding risk.
CHADS₂ Score 3: High stroke risk (5.9% per year). Strong recommendation for anticoagulation therapy with warfarin or direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs).
CHADS₂ Score 4: High stroke risk (8.5% per year). Strong recommendation for anticoagulation therapy with warfarin or direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs).
CHADS₂ Score 5: Very high stroke risk (12.5% per year). Strong recommendation for anticoagulation therapy with warfarin or direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs).
CHADS₂ Score 6: Very high stroke risk (18.2% per year). Strong recommendation for anticoagulation therapy with warfarin or direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs).

references: Gage BF, Waterman AD, Shannon W, Boechler M, Rich MW, Radford MJ. Validation of clinical classification schemes for predicting stroke: results from the National Registry of Atrial Fibrillation. JAMA. 2001;285(22):2864-70.

Gage BF, van Walraven C, Pearce L, Hart RG, Koudstaal PJ, Boode BS, Petersen P. Selecting patients with atrial fibrillation for anticoagulation: stroke risk stratification in patients taking aspirin. Circulation. 2004;110(16):2287-92.

Olesen JB, Lip GY, Hansen ML, Hansen PR, Tolstrup JS, Lindhardsen J, Selmer C, Ahlehoff O, Olsen AM, Gislason GH, Torp-Pedersen C. Validation of risk stratification schemes for predicting stroke and thromboembolism in patients with atrial fibrillation: nationwide cohort study. BMJ. 2011;342:d124.

Singer DE, Albers GW, Dalen JE, Fang MC, Go AS, Halperin JL, Lip GY, Manning WJ; American College of Chest Physicians. Antithrombotic therapy in atrial fibrillation: American College of Chest Physicians Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines (8th Edition). Chest. 2008;133(6 Suppl):546S-592S.
formula: CHADS₂ Score = Congestive heart failure (1) + Hypertension (1) + Age ≥75 years (1) + Diabetes mellitus (1) + Stroke/TIA/thromboembolism history (2). Total range: 0-6 points.
notes: CHADS₂ acronym: C-Congestive heart failure, H-Hypertension, A-Age ≥75, D-Diabetes, S₂-Stroke/TIA/thromboembolism (2 points)
Developed from National Registry of Atrial Fibrillation in 2001
Score 0: 1.9% annual stroke risk - consider CHA₂DS₂-VASc for further stratification
Score 1: 2.8% annual stroke risk - intermediate risk category
Score 2: 4.0% annual stroke risk - generally recommend anticoagulation
Score ≥3: 5.9-18.2% annual stroke risk - strong anticoagulation recommendation
Validated in multiple populations and healthcare systems
Largely superseded by CHA₂DS₂-VASc score for more comprehensive risk assessment
Better at identifying high-risk patients than truly low-risk patients
Among patients 65-95 years, <7% classified as low risk
Does not capture all stroke risk factors (vascular disease, gender, age 65-74)
Simple bedside calculation makes it clinically practical
Used for anticoagulation decision-making in atrial fibrillation
Score ≥2 generally indicates anticoagulation benefit outweighs bleeding risk
Consider bleeding risk assessment (HAS-BLED) alongside stroke risk
